factoid: Moscow society received Pierre like a long-expected guest whose place was always ready awaiting Pierre.
For Moscow society, Pierre was the nicest, kindest, most intellectual, merriest, and most magnanimous of cranks, a heedless, genial nobleman of the old Russian type.
Pierre's purse was always empty because it was open to everyone.
Pierre gave benefit performances, poor pictures, statues, benevolent societies, gypsy choirs, schools, subscription dinners, sprees, Freemasons, churches, and books to everyone.
Pierre would have given everything away if not for two friends who had borrowed large sums from him and taken him under their protection.
There was never a dinner or soiree at the club without Pierre.
As soon as Pierre sank into his place on the sofa after two bottles of Margaux, he was surrounded, and talking, disputing, and joking began.
When there were quarrels, Pierre's kindly smile and well-timed jests reconciled the antagonists.
Masonic dinners were dull and dreary when Pierre was not there.
After a bachelor supper, Pierre rose with his amiable and kindly smile, yielding to the entreaties of the festive company to drive off somewhere with them.
Shouts of delight and triumph arose among the young men when Pierre joined them.
Pierre danced at balls if a partner was needed.
Young ladies, married and unmarried, liked Pierre because he was equally amiable to all without making love to any of them, especially after supper.
Pierre was charming and had no sex.
Pierre was one of the retired gentlemen-in-waiting of whom there were hundreds in Moscow.
Pierre was horrified seven years before when he first arrived from abroad, having been told that there was no need for him to seek or plan anything.
Pierre was told that his rut had long been shaped, eternally predetermined, and that he would be what all in his position were.
Pierre could not have believed that he would be predetermined.
Pierre once longed with all his heart to establish a republic in Russia.
Pierre once desired to be a Napoleon.
Pierre once desired to be a philosopher.
Pierre once desired to be a strategist and the conqueror of Napoleon.
Pierre desired the regeneration of the sinful human race.
Pierre desired his own progress to the highest degree of perfection.
Pierre established schools and hospitals.
Pierre liberated his serfs.
Pierre was a wealthy husband of an unfaithful wife.
Pierre was a retired gentleman-in-waiting.
Pierre was fond of eating and drinking.
Pierre abused the government a bit when he unbuttoned his waistcoat.
Pierre was a member of the Moscow English Club.
Pierre was a universal favorite in Moscow society.
Pierre could not reconcile himself to the idea that he was one of the retired Moscow gentlemen-in-waiting he had despised seven years before.
Pierre consoled himself by thinking that he was only living this life temporarily.
Pierre was shocked by how many, like him, had entered that life and club temporarily.
Pierre realized that many had left the club when not a single tooth or hair remained.
In moments of pride, Pierre thought that he was different and distinct from the other retired gentlemen-in-waiting he had despised.
Pierre believed that the other retired gentlemen-in-waiting were empty, stupid, and contented.
Pierre believed that he was discontented and wanted to do something for mankind.
Pierre thought that his comrades struggled just like him and sought something new.
Pierre thought that his comrades were brought by force of circumstances, society, and race to the condition he was in.
Pierre said to himself in moments of humility that he no longer despised his comrades.
Pierre began to grow fond of, respect, and pity his comrades.
Pierre pitied himself.
